subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
msgSnippet: Paige: I applaud your efforts at providing a larger body of Quickscript material.Your email did not ask for a critique - but I just love doing them.  It s not
messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
Paige:

I applaud your efforts at providing a larger body of Quickscript material.Your email did not ask for a critique - but I just love doing them.  It's not that I know that much, but I learn a lot more looking at another person's work than my own.

As you will see, I am not about to get into the "correct" pronunciation quagmire, except in one instance, where I found it not correct, or incorrect, but an interesting option.  I hope this doesn't crash your fancy system . Here goes:



Witches' scene from Shakespeare's Macbeth - written out in full with no abbreviations or half-letters.  I do use the seven standard abbreviations which Read suggested even writers of junior Quikscript should use.
1 wic.  `eG SAl wI TrI mIt agiG?
Since this is a poem, and most lines rhyme, I could see the possibility of spelling this agEn, to get the same vowel sound as rEG. It's an advantage of the Shavian system that author's could dictate exactly how they want their words pronounced. (I bet in Shakespeare's day the two words did rhyme without forcing.)
        iG TandD, lFtGIN, P iG rEG?
Taking the word rFtiN from Pg 24 of the Quickscript manual as a guide, "lightning" should read lFtGiN

2 wic.  `eG H hDlIbDlIz dan,
        `eG H bAtulz lYst And wan.
Androcles uses in Shavian script lost instead of lYst.  lYst suggests a really broad vowel sound as in "law" lY. Southerners here in America would say  lYst, but most of the rest of the country would be more inclined to  lost. But this is the kind of nit-picking I vowed not get into.

3 wic.  HAt wil b X H set v san.
1 wic.  `X H plEs?
2 wic.  apoG H hIT.
3 wic.  HX tM mIt wiT /mAkbeT.
1 wic.  F kam, /grEmYlkin.
2 wic.  pAdak kYlz.
3 wic.  anoG !
Yl.  fX z fQl, And fQl z fX:
        havD TrM H [an oddity here:my text adds <fog n>] filTI X.

/mAkbeT   Akt wan, sIn wan
The same scene using the standard abbreviations and half-letters:
If the first word is really "the", and you choose not to use the abbreviation H then is'nt He more correct? If the second word is supposed to be "same", I would say sEm . If the third word is "scene", then it should be written as it was the line  above <sIn>. "Using" (like "musing") would be <Msing> No need to repeat the sound b twice in abbreviations and I hear a z at the end not an s.

1 wic.  `eG Sl w TrI mIt agiG?
        iG TandD, lFtGIN, P iG rEG?
Again on page 24, the Senior script version of "writing" is rFtN , so lightning would be lFtGN.
2 wic.  `eG H hDlIbDlIz dan,
    `eG H bAtulz lYst n @an.
3 wic.  Ht l b X H set v san.
1 wic.  `X H plEs?
2 wic.  apoG H hIT.
3 wic.  HX t mIt wi /mAkbeT.
1 wic.  F km, /grEmYlkin.
2 wic.  pAdak kYlz.
3 wic.  anoG !
Yl.  fX z fQl, n fQl z fX:
      havD TrM H filTI X.

Now how about the other Five Acts....?


I have attached an example of Junior and Senior Quikscript to this
post.  I had to use an attachment because I got sick of Windows crashing
all the time and switched to using Linux for my operating system.  I am
running Windows 98 in a window under Linux.  I haven't figured out how
to get Jerome into the Linux side of my computer yet.  (I'm not even
sure its possible since it is a truetype font.)

Paige Gabhart
